beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle generously given to me by theisti after its release and kept in the fridge since. Pours a deep mahogany with a thin beige head of tiny bubbles. The nose is of sour cherries and candy sugar. The mouthfeel, however, has none of the sweetness found in the aroma. Medium-bodied & tart with a very dry finish. The flavor follows the aroma with tart sour cherry and a dry, funky, yeasty backing. This is very good stuff. Thank you again, Tim.

355 ml bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a loose, white head that quickly drops to a swirling nebula of tiny bubbles at the surface. The nose is a dry lemongrass tartness with a mineral-farmhouse yeast backing. Light-bodied and effervescent, it finishes pleasantly tart without being puckering. The flavor is of tart, lightly lemony mineral water with fine carbonation and a touch of malt sweetness transitioning to slightly dry finish. This is a very refreshing and tasty gueuze.

Pours jet black with a mocha head. The nose is of dark roasted malt, bitter and milk chocolate and a hint of coffee. Full-bodied and oily with tongue tickling carbonation. The flavor is of dark roasted malt, salted burnt caramel, dark chocolate, and piny hops. A solid American rendition of the style.

Pours a deep brown with a thin ring of mocha bubbles clinging to the glass. The nose is of sweet and sour grape notes along with some barrel woodiness. Medium bodied and vinous with a drying tannic finish. The flavor is almost like a fruity red wine pitched with brett. This is a unique and very tasty beer.

Pours inky black with a small ring of small, tan bubbles around the glass. The nose is of dark roasted malt, coffee, and a light soy sauce. Medium to full-body and slick with light, fine carbonation; its a bit astringent in the finish. The flavor follows the nose with the addition of a piny hop note and a little sourness at the finish.

Pours an amber-orange with a short off-white head. The nose is fairly muted for a barleywine: a sweet, somewhat biscuity caramel malt note with a touch of dates. Medium-bodied with soft carbonation and a bit of alcohol warmth at a fairly sweet finish. The flavor is similar to the nose. Surprisingly sweet for a beer this big. The flavor is a lighter than many barleywines. Instead of dark fruit and brown sugar notes., it is more bright caramel malt with some green, piny hops and a sweet fruity note of dried dates. This is a solid barleywine, but its just a bit too sweet for my tastes.

Pours a deep mahogany with a thin khaki head. The nose is of raisins, brown sugar, plum and a round, sweet, dark malt. Medium to full-bodied and oily with a mildy astringent finish. The flavor is of sweet dark fruit, candy sugar and enough herbal hop bitterness, at the swallow, to keep it from becoming cloying.

Pours a nearly clear mahogany with a short tan head. The nose is of dark chocolate, coffee, and dark roasty malt with a light, sweet smoke note. Medium-bodied and slick with fine carbonation and a mildly roasty and bitter finish. The flavor is of coffee, dark roasted malt, and bitter chocolate. The finish has a bit of a piny hop note. This is a pretty tasty beer.
beer_name: Ass Kisser Stubborn Jack Smoked Porter

review_blob: Pours a hazy copper with a fluffy, pitted, ecru head that leaves a ladder of lace as it retreats. The nose unsurprisingly is of citrus notes (blood orange and red grapefruit) an passion fruit over a slightly biscuity malt backing. Medium-bodied and soft on-the-tongue, it becomes a touch grainy and notably more bitter with a drying, pucker at the finish. The flavor follows the nose with a lingering, hoppy bitterness that compels you to take another sip. This is a tasty and very sessionable IPA. Nicely done.

Pours a nearly clear pale gold with a wispy white head. The nose is a soft wheat with a peppery Belgian yeast strain backed by floral and herbal hops. Medium-bodied with a slight mineral water quality and a fairly dry and bitter finish. The flavor is of cereal grain with a white pepper supporting note and somewhat puckering bright, herbal hop finish. Tasty stuff.

Bottle; 2000 release. Pours an opaque mahogany with a thin off-white cap. The nose is of big, round, raisiny malt and brown sugar. Full-bodied and softly carbonated, it finishes with a lingering sweetness and a bit of oxidation/cardboard-iness. The flavor is quite sweet: molasses, sweet sherry and dark fruit malt notes give way to an aftertaste accompanied by lighter notes of Granny Smith tartness and cardboard. One could argue that 13 years in-the-bottle is too long for this beer. Others, myself among them, could argue that the effects of oxidation have added some complexity to the proceedings.

Bottle courtesy of theisti. Pours a chestnut brown with a khaki two-finger head. The nose is of dark, almost burnt caramel and biscuits. Medium-bodied with soft, fine carbonation and a drying, mildly astringent finish. The flavor follows the aroma: round, malty and fairly dry, with a dry, slightly herbal finish. This is an interesting rendition on the style. Thanks again for the bottle, Tim.

Pours a deep garnet with a short, creamy, light tan head. The nose is of peat and burnt caramel. Medium-bodied with a drying, mildly astringent finish. The flavor follows the aroma: peat, burnt caramel and a light peanut note A solid beer.

Bottle courtesy of theisti. Pours a hazy mahogany with a fluffy ecru head. The nose is of plum, red grape, black cherry, and a faint dustiness. The palate is medium-bodied and vinous, with a drying, tannic finish. Following the nose, the flavor profile is a bit tart and vinous featuring similar dark fruit notes to those in the aroma. This bottle is a couple years old. So, Im not sure if its representative of a fresher batch (especially as its fairly atypical for the style), but its pretty damned good. Thanks again for the bottle, Tim.
beer_name: The Duck-Rabbit Wee Heavy Scotch Style Ale

review_blob: Pours a clear golden amber with a loose off-white head. The nose is of citric and piny hops over a solid biscuity malt backing. Medium-bodied and slightly grainy with a moderately bitter, lingering, resinous finish. The flavor is a big hit of citric hop notes (grapefruit, orange and star fruit) with a sweet, caramel malt backbone maintaining a sweet counterbalance into a lingering hop bitterness. A touch of pine joins the citrus notes in the finish and aftertaste. This is a big IPA that almost pushes into IIPA territory.
beer_name: Lagunitas A Little Sumpin Sumpin Ale

review_blob: Bottle a friend brought back from Montana. Pours a deep brown, almost black, with a small khaki head and a thin layer of yeast that settles at the bottom of the glass. The nose is a blend of caramel, cocoa, and a nondeScript fruit note. On the light side of medium-bodied, the palate is fairly effervescent with a mineral quality at the finish. The flavor adds an almost smoky roasted malt flavor to notes found on the nose. It also has a lot less of the sweet fruitiness and adds a bit of salt to the mix. Overall, thus is an interesting porter. Thanks for bringing this back for me, Deana.

2007 bomber courtesy of theisti. Pours jet black with a dark cocoa head that drops to a thin skin at the surface of the snifter. The nose is of dark roasted malt, oak, vanilla, licorice and touch of bourbon sweetness. Full-bodied and slick with just a bit of oaky dryness and some astringency at the swallow. I have taken good care of this bottle, saving it for the opportunity to share it with a friend, but I was a little concerned Id held onto it for too long. Fortunately, the wax seal seams to have done its job. The flavor is of dark, roasty malt, coffee, oak/vanilla barrel notes and a touch of the bourbon that may have once been "hot" but has mellowed to an added sweetness that enhances the profile. This is a great beer, and I had the added pleasure of getting to share it with a good friend (who also loved it). Thank you again for this amazing gift, Tim.

Pours a cloudy straw with a loose, fluffy, white head that leaves patchy lace on the glass. The nose is of citric and herbal hops alongside candy sugar and wheat malt notes. The palate is light-bodied with fairly soft carbonation and a touch of a sour-twinge bitterness at the finish. Citric hops backed by a wheaty malt backing, the hop flavor lingers in the finish without the lingering bitterness you get from an IPA (or an APA for that matter). This is an interesting beer, I cant think of any other "hoppy wheat" beers, that Ive tried, where the hop presence is so pronounced in the nose and flavor profiles but so conspicuously absent on the palate. Without the tongue-squeezing bitterness of a Gumballhead or Schneider-Brooklyner collaboration, this may not fill-the-bill for someone craving hop bitterness, but it is definitely one of the most flavorful and sessionable wheat beers on the market, today. Nice job guys.

Growler; in a weizen glass. Pours a clear gold with a tall, fluffy white head that drops faster than its unfiltered brethren. The aroma is of cotton candy and banana with a light clove note in the background. Light-bodied and mildly effervescent with a fairly crisp finish. The flavor follows the nose: cotton candy and banana notes over a mildly wheaty malt backing and just a touch of drying astringency at the finish. While kristalweizens are generally lighter-bodied and, consequently, a bit more quaffable than standard hefeweizens, I always find myself missing the wheaty mouthfeel and bolder yeast contributions the latter possess. That said, this is still a tasty beer and a good example of the style.

Pours an orange-amber with a frothy beige head and sticky lace. The nose is a huge punch of grapefruit and blood orange with just enough caramel malt in the background to realize Im not just smelling hop cones. Medium to full-bodied with a solid, tongue-squeezing bitterness. The flavor follows the nose and the name with a huge slap of critic, resinous hops that linger as though Im sucking on hop pellets. Theres enough malt backing to keep it from becoming puckeringly bitter, but dont even think about including this beer in a flight or tasting session, unless you place it dead last in the session. If you dont, you wont be able to taste any of the other beers after this one. While a hop heads delight, this is one over-the-top beer. I must try pairing this with Thai-hot take out. Thats pretty much the only thing I can think of that could stand up to this beer.

500 MLB bottle. Pours jet black with a short, tan head that quickly drops to a thin skin of tiny bubbles. The aroma is sweet blend of dark fruit and dark roasted malt; like a hybrid of a stout & a barley wine. Medium-bodied with soft, fine carbonation and a somewhat drying, vinous finish. The flavor profile leans much farther toward the sweet fruity side of the aroma than I expected: plum, red grapes, and dark fruity and roasty malt. While its not quite what I was expecting, its a well-made and tasty beer.

Bomber. Pours deep brown (almost black) with mahogany highlights and a dense, creamy, khaki head that pits, as it recedes, leaving a web of lace upon the glass. The aroma is a blend of dark roast and caramel malt notes, coffee and a bit of cocoa; pretty nice. Medium-bodied and silky-slick on the tongue with a roasty bitter finish that gets an added bump from the bittering hops. The flavor is essentially a compilation of all the previously mentioned notes along with the addition of a bright/"green" hop contribution and a touch of dark roasted ashiness. Altogether, it just works. It works so well, in fact, that this may very well become my new go-to porter. This is an exceptional beer.

Pours a bright gold with a white frothy head that leaves heavy sticky lace on the glass. Once a bit of the yeast hit the pour, it immediately changed to a less attractive, murky tannish-amber. The nose is of sweet apple, candy sugar and pear over a light pale malt note. Medium-bodied with soft, fine carbonation leading to a drying, almost tannic, finish. The flavor is of pear, mild apple cider and a touch of cardboard over pale malt. One of the fruitiest tripels Ive ever had, I may have held on to this one a touch too long, but Ill definitely buy this one again to sample it a bit younger. Good stuff.

12 oz bottle. Pours a bright hazy gold with a towering fluffy white head. Adding the last inch of the bottle instantly alters the appearance to a murky deep amber with a lot of uniform particles/yeast at the base of the tulip. The nose is of mildly fruity (citrus-apple) and spicy Belgian yeast, along with an odd, mineral-like hydrogen peroxide note over pale malt. Light to medium bodied with fine effervescent carbonation that leads to a drying mineral finish with a touch of spicy cardboard. The palate more-or-less follows the nose with some additional tart fruitiness improving the blend. The high carbonation and mineral qualities are a bit off-putting for me, but I generally dislike those qualities in all but a few styles. I think I may have kept this bottle in my cellar/fridge longer than its 7% might warrant, but this is an interesting "imperial wit". Its interesting enough, in fact, that should I find it again, I would likely snag another bottle to see how it tastes while a bit younger.
beer_name: Big Hole Mythical White Grand Reserve

review_blob: Pours into a towering, loose, fluffy, off-white head that takes its time receding into a hazy amber-orange body. The nose is a blend of dry Brettiness and light, fruity yeast notes (pear and apple). Also present is a distinct vinyl note that is a surprisingly pleasant addition to the medley. Once the head dissipates, however, the vinyl note nearly disappears and the aroma becomes more integrated with a touch of spice added to the mix. The palate is light to medium-bodied with soft, fine carbonation and a drying, somewhat tart and moderately funky/sour (good funk) finish. The flavor is less fruity than the nose, with the Brett dominating the flavor profile: horse blanket funk and a mild white pepper note take front stage over a pale malt back that just hints at the apple and pear notes found in the aroma. Quite drying and funky with additional phantom notes of leather and peach pit dancing in and out of focus. This is the kind of beer that could simultaneously scare craft beer newbies away from "Belgian-Style" Pale Ales and make Brett fans hear "Ode to Joy" in their heads. I lie somewhere between those two groups. I enjoy the nuances that it possesses but I would have preferred it have dialed-in closer to where the nose is at this point. This is definitely an interesting beer, and if Brett is your thing, this is a good candidate to cellar and crack one every 3-6 months to see how it evolves.

Pours a hazy straw with a towering, pillowing, white head. The nose is a pleasant blend of wheat malt, some faint toffee, and a mildly, spicy, earthy and fruity English hop note. Light-bodied with a soft, "wheaty" mouthfeel, the palate concludes in a mildly bitter, drying finish. The flavor mirrors the nose with a nice spicy/fruity hop profile over a wheat malt backbone. I like a lot of wheat beers, but I dont generally care all that much for a lot of English-style hops. So this effective blend of, what I would have thought were strange bedfellows, has really surprised me. This is a tasty beer, and I will definitely be purchasing more this summer.

Pours a slightly hazy mahogany with a thin khaki head. The nose is of raisins and dark fruit malt notes. On the light side of medium-bodied, the mouthfeel is fairly soft with fine carbonation leading into a surprisingly dry finish for this style. Raisins, dark fruit and a drying astringent burnt malt notes combine into a slightly unconventional flavor profile. While Im seldom "wowed" by dubbels, this is still a solid beer.

Pours a hazy iced tea brown with a pillowy ecru head that deposits sticky lace upon the glass. The nose is a spicy/critic blend of rye and PNW hops. On the light side of medium-bodied, the palate transitions from fine, tongue-tickling carbonation to a spicy/bitter finish. The rye hits hard up-front, in the flavor profile, and it hangs on throughout. While the C-hops try to push forward, they never take front-stage. I like most of the RyePAs that Ive tried, where the rye note in them is generally more of a spicy accent to a traditional IPA. Here it adds a dominant pepper/spicy character to the beer that deemphasizes the hop contributions to the flavor. I like it, but I think I prefer my RyePAs to lean more on their hop contributions .

Bomber. Pours a nearly-clear golden amber with a loose, frothy, off-white head that leaves spotty lace on the glass. The nose is fruity and floral with some bubble gum (odd for the style) and just a touch of dried pine needles and metal over a subtle pale malt backing. On the light-side of medium-bodied, it is fairly soft on-the-tongue, transitioning to a moderately bitter aftertaste that waits a few beats after you swallow before showing itself, by squeezing at the sides of your tongue. A disconnect from the nose, the flavor is a blend of floral and piny hop notes with the latter significantly more pronounced than in the aroma. It meanders from fruity and floral up-front with a little malt sweetness toward a somewhat resinous, lingering piny note at the finish and long beyond. This is a beer for which the hops are most pronounced in the flavor versus the nose and palate. An interesting pale ale, unlike any other that I think Ive sampled, in memory. For that, alone, it wins some brownie points. This is a solid session beer.

Batch 67299; one of the first bottled batches from June 2007. As a KC native and resident, I have had this beer a few times, but Ive never rated it. So, when I discover this overlooked bottle, in my cellar, I felt compelled to crack it open and see what four-plus years had done to it. It pours a murky mahogany with a small beige head that drops to a creamy cap at the surface; some spotty lace sticks to the glass. (The head is considerably larger with a fresher batch.) On the nose are notes of dark fruit (plum, raisin, dates), sherry and slightly spicy alcohol. You can tell, just from the aroma, that this is a big beer. The palate is medium-bodied with fine carbonation and a drying, somewhat bitter finish that shows a bit of this bottles age with a touch of a cardboard quality at the finish. The flavor effectively mimic the aroma. The fruity/sherry quality pushes forward and really adds an interesting complimentary character to a beer that is pretty solid when fresh. Im not sure that I like it better than a younger batch, but its pretty tasty stuff.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Sixth Glass Quadrupel

review_blob: Bottle; served in a footed pilsner glass. Pours a nearly-clear gold with a pillowy, pitted head that leaves patchy lace upon the glass. The nose is of doughy French bread with just the slightest whisper of earthy/grassy hops; very clean. Light-bodied and fairly slick with tiny carbonation bubbles adding some texture to the mix as you swallow into a fairly clean finish. Just a touch of mineral quality lingers on the tongue. The flavor follows the nose, with the dominant characteristic being doughy, light malt leading into a crisp finish. Given the style, theres not really a whole lot going on with this one, but its a solid, drinkable version of a style that I generally dont care for a whole lot. At $4 a sixer, this is a very affordable lawnmower beer that supports a small brewer versus the megalith international brewers.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale brown, like iced tea with lemon squeezed into it, with an ecru head that drops fairly quickly. The nose is of sweet, slightly doughy caramel malt; very clean. The palate is light-bodied with a mild mineral quality that leads into a drying finish. Following the aroma, the flavor is of sweet, doughy, and slightly biscuity malt backed by just a hint of earthy hops. This is a pretty solid Vienna, and at 4 bucks per sixer, its a heckuva value as well.

Bottle. Pours a clear gold with a fluffy white head that slowly drops leaving sticky lace upon the glass. The nose is an enticing blend of big grapefruit and softer piny hop notes over a sweet pale malt. Medium-bodied and soft with a big tongue-squeezing bitterness at the finish. Like the nose, the flavor is a big hit of grapefruit hops over pale malt with a lingering slightly resinous finish. This is some tasty stuff. I hope they screw up their brewing schedule again next year.

Bottle. Pours a clear chestnut brown with a small beige head that diminishes to a thin cap. The nose is of dark fruity malt with a vinous quality to it, like a spiced plum pudding. Medium-bodied with fine carbonation and a fairly neutral finish. The malt-forward flavor is of plum, brown sugar and baking spices with bit of a spicy hop note coming forward at the finish. While I dont generally care for a lot of spiced "winter warmers", this one manages to be sweet and spicy without being cloying or overly spicy. I like it.

Bottle. Pours a clear iced tea brown with a loose off-white head that leaves a web of lace upon the glass. The nose is of biscuity malt backed by citrus, sweet/tropical fruit and (rye-like) spicy notes. Medium-bodied and silky-soft with a lingering, tongue-squeezing, and moderately resinous bitter-hopped finish. The flavor is a step up from the nose, with citrus and passion fruit hop notes over a soft, biscuity malt backing transitioning to a long bitter finish. While the aromatic additions took a back-seat to the malt, on the nose, the hops definitely take front-stage in the flavor profile. As I get deepen into the glass, my enjoyment of this one begins to wane a bit. While the hop profile is interesting, it begins to strip the tongue of moisture leaving a long, "green", herbal bitterness that Im not really digging. Its certainly not something I would consider sessionable.

Pours a deep brown with a loose khaki head that sticks around for a while and leaves a web of lace, as it drops. The nose is a pleasant, sweet blend of mildly nutty malt and herbal and piny hop notes. It smells like a lighter, brighter version of some of the India brown ales that Ive tried. Light-bodied and slick with a solidly bitter finish that lingers, softly, after the swallow. The flavor is a solid hit of herbal and piny hops over a moderately sweet cocoa-ish malt base along with the signature nutty/peanut-ty New Belgium yeast flavor I get from many of their beers. Overall, this is pretty good stuff.

Pours a pale, clear brown with a tall, fluffy, khaki head that drops quickly (especially for a wheat beer) to a thin cap. The nose is of sweet peach and wheat malt notes supported by a lesser nutty (pecan?) note. Light-bodied and softly "grainy", the mouthfeel finishes with a slight mineral-dryness. The flavor follows the nose: peach-forward with subtle dark wheat and pecan notes. The idea behind this beer intrigues me, but the execution falls short of what a bolder, fuller-bodied peach dunkelweizen could be. If they dared to amp-up the recipe and bottle it unfiltered, Spoetzl could have a real winner here. As it is, however, its just another unremarkable fruit beer.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2011

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Pours a translucent black with mahogany highlights and a loose, pitted, beige head. The nose is of toasty caramel malt and cocoa mixed with mineral water. Fairly light-bodied but with an almost seltzer water-like effervescence, the mouthfeel is a bit offputting. That carries into the flavor profile, where it seems like a schwarzbier spritzer: the traditional flavors are there but they are muted by the seltzer/mineral water character. While I would prefer a softer mouthful and fuller flavor, this is an interesting rendition of the style.

Tulip at Barleyss Brewhaus in Shawnee. Pours jet black with a thin, creamy beige head. The nose is a nicely integrated blend of cocoa, coffee and roasted malt. Medium-bodied and slick with a roasty finish; just a touch of hop bitterness. The flavor follows the nose with a touch of earthy hops in the mix. Nice beer.
beer_name: Grand Teton Wake Up Call Imperial Coffee Porter

review_blob: Pours a translucent chestnut with a creamy off-white head. The nose is fairly simple with nutty toasty malt with a touch of sugar thrown-in. On the light side of medium-bodied the palate is fairly slick up  until the swallow when fine carbonation accents a slightly astringent finish. The flavor is of nutty malt with  a sourish transition to a burnt toasty finish. Overall, its a fairly typical brown: decent but not particularly exciting. If you enjoy this style, its certainly worth trying at 3 bucks for a bomber.

Shaker at the brewpub. Pours a pretty reddish copper with a creamy beige head. The nose is bright, spicy and floral over a subdued pale malt note. On the light side of medium-bodied, it is slightly grainy with a solid spicy and bitter-hopped finish. This beer really "popped" on first sip: floral up front then quite spicy with rye and piny hop notes wrestling for your attention. Theres nothing subtle about this beer and Im digging it. More than a couple of these would wreck you palate for a while, but youll smile while it happens. Another solid IPA from Free State. Ive come to expect nothing less, and they continue to deliver.
beer_name: Free State Ramble on Rose Rye

review_blob: Shaker at the brewpub. Pours a pale copper with a thin beige head and spotty lace. The nose is of simcoe and amarillo hops over a slightly sweet, biscuity malt. Fairly light-bodied and grainy with a drying bitter finish. The flavor is an Americanized hop-forward rendition of the style; follows the nose. Nicely dry and moderately bitter, I could session this all night.

Pours a fairly clear pale gold with an explosive fluffy white head. The first pour was about 15% beer and 85% towering, expanding head. As it recedes, it leaves behind sticky, patchy lace. Adding to the glass again results in a pillar of foam rising out of the glass. (After rating over 1200 beers, Ive never seen a beer behave like this.) The aroma is a muted blend of cereal grain, club soda and a strawberry candy-like note. The palate is light-bodied but comes across as more substantial due to the significant amount of fine carbonation that it possesses. It finishes fairly dry, especially for this style, with a mineral-like quality lingering past the swallow. The flavor is of faint cereal malt blended with a strawberry seltzer water. I could see someone drinking this on a hot summer day, as it does have a "refreshing" quality about it, and its not saccharin-sweet like a fruit/wine cooler. It just doesnt have the flavor to match its effervescence.

Pours a dark golden amber with a sizable, fluffy ecru head that deposits cascading lace upon the glass. The nose is a solid hit of dank, resinous, citric, grassy and slightly piny hops over a backing of sweet pale malt: nice. The palate is on the light side of medium-bodied and slick with a rolling bitter-hopped finish that lingers long after the swallow. The flavor is a hop-forward blend of piny, grassy and slightly citric hop notes with just enough malt sweetness to keep the massive, resinous hop profile in-check. After the swallow, however, a lingering pine resin squeezes your tongue until you take another sip to reintroduce some malt sweetness back into the game.This beer, when fresh, is an excellent primer to show someone the difference between a harvest/fresh hop beer and one made with pellets. The hops and their bright bitterness just "sing" in this beer. After years of watching dozens of bottles linger on store shelves, Im very glad to have found a fresh bottle to sample this year. If youre a hop-head and dont need "balance", snag a bottle of this while its still fresh.
beer_name: Great Divide Fresh Hop Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle I acquired from daknole over 2 1/2 years ago. Pours a deep, opaque brown with a thin cocoa head that drops quickly to an island of bubbles at the surface and spotty lace on the glass. The nose is big and malty with a sweet spiciness, vanilla, creme brulee with some cinnamon, and a sweet woodiness unlike cherry, oak or any other wood addition Ive encountered. Medium-bodied and oily slick with a sweet finish transitioning to a woody, and just slightly hoppy bitter finish/aftertaste. The flavor is quite sweet, possessing many of the same sweet and spicy complexities found on the nose with the addition of a pronounced ashiness and a significantly drying woody finish. This is some really interesting stuff. The wood helps to counterbalance the significant sweetness, but overall, I found the otherwise pleasant wood note to be a bit overbearing after the swallow. Among the DFH "experiments" that Ive tried this one fall into the success category. Unlike any other beer that Ive tried it also possesses the admirable quality of being pretty tasty. Thanks again, Dak. :)

Pours a still burgundy with a touch of bubbles that quickly reduce to a completely still surface. The nose is sherry-like with sweet dark fruit notes dominating a vinous aroma. Medium-bodied and slick with a vinous almost tannic quality at the sweet, slightly boozy conclusion. Sweet and somewhat tart, like a Granny Smith apple, a supporting raisin note leads into a drying finish that whispers a remembrance of the hop bill originally present in the recipe (8 years ago). With the exception of the finish, this more closely resembles a brandy than any other beer that Ive ever sampled. To be more accurate, its more of a hybrid between a barley wine and an apple brandy. This is some interesting stuff. Thanks for recommending it, Aaron.

Bottle courtesy of my friend Deana. Pours an attractive burnt orange with a loose, frothy off-white head. The nose is a blend of pumpkin pie spices over a brown/amber malty nose. Fairly typical for the style, the aroma, however, is pretty well-integrated and a solid "notch" above-par. Light to medium-bodied and soft with a drying and slightly astringent finish. The flavor profile is an odd if not interesting one: the pumpkin spice dominates a brown ale profile that hides behind with a mineral water quality thrown into the mix. While on-the-tongue it seems fairly spice forward and almost heavy-handed, but after the swallow, the lingering flavor mellows and is actually pretty pleasant. If the entire flavor profile could replicate the aftertaste, this would be a top-tier example of the style. As it is, however, its simply "better than average". With both Schlaflys and Southern Tiers pumpkin offerings locally available, I dont think its too likely that Ill be returning to this one any time soon, but I certainly appreciated the opportunity to sample it. Thanks again, Deana. :)

Pours a fairly clear dark chestnut with a fluffy tan head. The nose is a nice blend of nutty malt with some cocoa and caramel in the mix along with some spicy and faintly piny hop notes. Medium-bodied and slightly "grainy" with a mild to moderately hoppy and gypsum-like drying finish. I found the flavor to be a sizable drop-off from the promising nose. The nutty malt quality is there (sans the cocoa and caramel) with an herbal, grassy and spicy hop presence that dominate the flavor profile. Simply put, the flavor isnt as well integrated as the aroma. It is drying, mineral-like and just too herbal, for my tastes. It seems like they tried to add so much to this recipe that it struggles to find any continuity. Its an interesting hybrid. Its just not one that I would likely purchase again.
